title: TNNT: The Named Entity Recognition Toolkit

sentences.text: Extraction of categorised named entities from text is a complex task given the availability of a variety of Named Entity Recognition (NER) models and the unstructured information encoded in different source document formats.
Processing the documents to extract text, identifying suitable NER models for a task, and obtaining statistical information is important in data analysis to make informed decisions.

This paper presents1 TNNT, a toolkit that automates the extraction of categorised named entities from unstructured information encoded in source documents, using diverse state-of-the-art (SOTA) Natural Language Processing (NLP) tools and NER models.

TNNT integrates 21 different NER models as part of a Knowledge Graph Construction Pipeline (KGCP) that takes a document set as input and processes it based on the defined settings, applying the selected blocks of NER models to output the results.
The toolkit generates all results with an integrated summary of the extracted entities, enabling enhanced data analysis to support the KGCP, and also, to aid further NLP tasks.
NER is a major component in NLP systems to extract information from unstructured text.
Recent advances in deep learning and NLP have resulted in the availability of a large number of NER tools and models for use which have enabled NER of different categories from text.

However, given the existence of a wide range of document formats, extracting information is difficult considering the preprocessing required prior to using NER tools and the challenge of identifying which models to use.

It is desirable to have a system that can provide (1) a uniform processing pipeline of different document formats, (2) easy selection of different NLP-NER models or tools, (3) an integrated summary of the entities identified by the models, and (4) basic functionalities to access the results; in order to enhance data analysis with accurate decisions and to provide a thorough overview of the data used.
This paper introduces TNNT2 .

Its main goal is to automate the extraction of categorised named entities from the unstructured information encoded in the source documents, using a wide range of recent SOTA NLP-NER tools and models.

TNNT is integrated with the “Metadata Extractor & Loader" (MEL) [10], which enables extraction of metadata and content-based information from various file formats such as .pdf, .docx, .xlsx, .msg, .csv, .txt, and .zip.
We have brought together the existing SOTA NER models and NLP tools under one toolkit, enabling effortless NER analysis for unstructured content-based information.

The motivations of the toolkit are: (1) to be able to easily pre-process documents for NER analysis, (2) to be able to easily use documents with different formats for NER analysis, (3) to hide usage variations across NER models and NLP tools, and bring them under one uniform pipeline, and (4) to provide a framework for analysing results from different NER models and NLP tools.

Having several SOTA models under one umbrella provides many benefits such as their easy execution and comparison, and, most interestingly, it can help to identify the most suited block of NER models for a specific task or input domain.
There are a wide range of libraries, such as NLTK [7], spaCy3, Stanford NER [8], Stanza [9], and Flair [1], that provide models facilitating NER.
To the best of our knowledge, there is no toolkit or system that unifies under one uniform pipeline several SOTA tools and models for NER: TNNT fills this void.
TNNT integrates 21 different NER models from 9 SOTA NLP tools (Table 1).
Some of these models are based on rule-based and statistical approaches whereas others are based on deep learning techniques4 .
These 21 models can identify up to 18 categories (Table 2) of named entities in text.
The system is capable of processing different models sequentially based on the input settings (processing blocks) defined by the user.
All textual content extracted by MEL is processable for TNNT with a hybrid processing data flow, either from/to a document store or via direct processing from the file system.
For data analysis tasks, TNNT keeps general statistics of the models and generates an integrated summary of all the identified entities.
The results are JSON files (one for each processed source document) with the list of models, categories, and identified entities.
For each recognised entity, the toolkit retrieves a set of information specific to the entity .

A built-in RESTful API provides various features to access, expand, complement, and co-relate the NER results by performing other NLP tasks, such as Part-Of-Speech (POS) tagging, dependency parsing, and co-reference resolution.
This comprehensive information facilitates the apprehension of the models as well the data used for NLP tasks in general and, in particular, for tasks associated with knowledge building.
TNNT was designed to systematically apply various NER models to analyse textual content extracted via MEL.
Whereas the latter implements several data extraction operations, the former provides a modular and extensible framework for NER analysis using multiple models and NLP tools.
In a nutshell, TNNT is fully integrated with MEL as shown in Figure 1.
The toolkit's processing model is depicted in Figure 2.

The first two blocks are orchestrated by MEL which establishes how TNNT will process a block sequence of NER models to apply over the input dataset (either from a document store or from a direct document processing immediately after the metadata extraction task).
TNNT's inner architecture is composed of a pre-processing module and one distinct module for each implemented NLP-NER tool and models.
Based on the input document formats (file extensions), the pre-processing module takes the extracted text data by MEL and cleans/prepares it for the NER analysis task.
The core analysis task on the input data is sequentially performed for all the selected NER models.
TNNT's modular design enables a smooth selection and processing mechanism of the NER models.
For each recognised entity, the toolkit retrieves its context information, and start/end indices in the document text.
Furthermore, it provides statistics of the entities identified by each model for respective categories along with the start/end timestamps and the duration taken by the models to run the NER task.
Table 3 gives an overview of the results obtained using some of the models for two publicly available datasets: CONLL 20036 and NIST IE-ER7 .
The toolkit has a set of comprehensive configuration files that specify all the required details and processing parameters for each implemented NLP tool and NER model.
Users can experiment with various models by simply defining the desired settings.

TNNT's RESTful API refines and improves the NER results by adding more processing layers of abstraction to perform several useful operations, such as POS tagging, dependency parsing, coreference resolution, aggregations, descriptive stats, and browsing capabilities, as shown in Figure 3.
This module allows users to smoothly traverse and retrieve the NER results.
Its specifications and usage can be found at the project's w3id URI.
TNNT provides a simple mechanism and uniform pipeline to extract categorised named entities from unstructured data using a diverse range of SOTA NLP tools and NER models.
This tool is still in its early stages of development.
It has been tested using thousands of different document formats and datasets as part of the “Australian Government Records Interoperability Framework" (AGRIF) project [4].

There are ongoing plans to integrate more NLP-NER tools and models into the architecture along with continuing evolving the RESTful API with complementary NLP tasks to enrich the NER results, in order to support KGCP tasks.

The major contributions of this toolkit are: (1) the ability to process different source document formats for NER; (2) the availability of 21 different SOTA NER models integrated into one system, enabling easy selection of models for NER; (3) the provision of an integrated summary of the results from different models; and (4) a RESTful API that enables easy access to NLP tasks that enrich the NER results from the models.

Entity-restful_api.label: RESTful API

Entity-modular_design.label: modular design
Entity-modular_design.description: Modular design is a design concept that emphasizes the creation of systems or structures composed of interchangeable and independent components, allowing for flexibility, scalability, and ease of maintenance.

summary:
Extraction of categorised named entities from text is a complex task given the availability of a variety of Named Entity Recognition (NER) models and the unstructured information encoded in different source document formats. Processing the documents to extract text, identifying suitable NER models for a task, and obtaining statistical information is important in data analysis to make informed decisions. This paper presents1 TNNT, a toolkit that automates the extraction of categorised named entities from unstructured information encoded in source documents, using diverse state-of-the-art (SOTA) Natural Language Processing (NLP) tools and NER models. TNNT integrates 21 different NER models as part of a Knowledge Graph Construction Pipeline (KGCP) that takes a document set as input and processes it based on the defined settings, applying the selected blocks of NER models to output the results. The toolkit generates all results with an integrated summary of the extracted entities, enabling enhanced data analysis to support the KGCP, and also, to aid further NLP tasks.

NER is a major component in NLP systems to extract information from unstructured text. Recent advances in deep learning and NLP have resulted in the availability of a large number of NER tools and models for use which have enabled NER of different categories from text. However, given the existence of a wide range of document formats, extracting information is difficult considering the preprocessing required prior to using NER tools and the challenge of identifying which models to use. It is desirable to have a system that can provide (1) a uniform processing pipeline of different document formats, (2) easy selection of different NLP-NER models or tools, (3) an integrated summary of the entities identified by the models, and (4) basic functionalities to access the results; in order to enhance data analysis with accurate decisions and to provide a thorough overview of the data used.

This paper introduces TNNT2 . Its main goal is to automate the extraction of categorised named entities from the unstructured information encoded in the source documents, using a wide range of recent SOTA NLP-NER tools and models. TNNT is integrated with the “Metadata Extractor & Loader" (MEL) [10], which enables extraction of metadata and content-based information from various file formats such as .pdf, .docx, .xlsx, .msg, .csv, .txt, and .zip. We have brought together the existing SOTA NER models and NLP tools under one toolkit, enabling effortless NER analysis for unstructured content-based information. The motivations of the toolkit are: (1) to be able to easily pre-process documents for NER analysis, (2) to be able to easily use documents with different formats for NER analysis, (3) to hide usage variations across NER models and NLP tools, and bring them under one uniform pipeline, and (4) to provide a framework for analysing results from different NER models and NLP tools. Having several SOTA models under one umbrella provides many benefits such as their easy execution and comparison, and, most interestingly, it can help to identify the most suited block of NER models for a specific task or input domain.

There are a wide range of libraries, such as NLTK [7], spaCy3, Stanford NER [8], Stanza [9], and Flair [1], that provide models facilitating NER. To the best of our knowledge, there is no toolkit or system that unifies under one uniform pipeline several SOTA tools and models for NER: TNNT fills this void.

TNNT integrates 21 different NER models from 9 SOTA NLP tools (Table 1). Some of these models are based on rule-based and statistical approaches whereas others are based on deep learning techniques4 . These 21 models can identify up to 18 categories (Table 2) of named entities in text. The system is capable of processing different models sequentially based on the input settings (processing blocks) defined by the user. All textual content extracted by MEL is processable for TNNT with a hybrid processing data flow, either from/to a document store or via direct processing from the file system.

For data analysis tasks, TNNT keeps general statistics of the models and generates an integrated summary of all the identified entities. The results are JSON files (one for each processed source document) with the list of models, categories, and identified entities. For each recognised entity, the toolkit retrieves a set of information specific to the entity . A built-in RESTful API provides various features to access, expand, complement, and co-relate the NER results by performing other NLP tasks, such as Part-Of-Speech (POS) tagging, dependency parsing, and co-reference resolution. This comprehensive information facilitates the apprehension of the models as well the data used for NLP tasks in general and, in particular, for tasks associated with knowledge building.

TNNT was designed to systematically apply various NER models to analyse textual content extracted via MEL. Whereas the latter implements several data extraction operations, the former provides a modular and extensible framework for NER analysis using multiple models and NLP tools. In a nutshell, TNNT is fully integrated with MEL as shown in Figure 1. The toolkit's processing model is depicted in Figure 2. The first two blocks are orchestrated by MEL which establishes how TNNT will process a block sequence of NER models to apply over the input dataset (either from a document store or from a direct document processing immediately after the metadata extraction task).

TNNT's inner architecture is composed of a pre-processing module and one distinct module for each implemented NLP-NER tool and models. Based on the input document formats (file extensions), the pre-processing module takes the extracted text data by MEL and cleans/prepares it for the NER analysis task. The core analysis task on the input data is sequentially performed for all the selected NER models. TNNT's modular design enables a smooth selection and processing mechanism of the NER models. For each recognised entity, the toolkit retrieves its context information, and start/end indices in the document text. Furthermore, it provides statistics of the entities identified by each model for respective categories along with the start/end timestamps and the duration taken by the models to run the NER task. Table 3 gives an overview of the results obtained using some of the models for two publicly available datasets: CONLL 20036 and NIST IE-ER7 . The toolkit has a set of comprehensive configuration files that specify all the required details and processing parameters for each implemented NLP tool and NER model. Users can experiment with various models by simply defining the desired settings.

TNNT's RESTful API refines and improves the NER results by adding more processing layers of abstraction to perform several useful operations, such as POS tagging, dependency parsing, coreference resolution, aggregations, descriptive stats, and browsing capabilities, as shown in Figure 3. This module allows users to smoothly traverse and retrieve the NER results. Its specifications and usage can be found at the project's w3id URI.

TNNT provides a simple mechanism and uniform pipeline to extract categorised named entities from unstructured data using a diverse range of SOTA NLP tools and NER models. This tool is still in its early stages of development. It has been tested using thousands of different document formats and datasets as part of the “Australian Government Records Interoperability Framework" (AGRIF) project [4]. There are ongoing plans to integrate more NLP-NER tools and models into the architecture along with continuing evolving the RESTful API with complementary NLP tasks to enrich the NER results, in order to support KGCP tasks. The major contributions of this toolkit are: (1) the ability to process different source document formats for NER; (2) the availability of 21 different SOTA NER models integrated into one system, enabling easy selection of models for NER; (3) the provision of an integrated summary of the results from different models; and (4) a RESTful API that enables easy access to NLP tasks that enrich the NER results from the models.

Predicate-is_a_complex_task_given_the_av.label: is a complex task given the availability of
Predicate-is_a_complex_task_given_the_av.description: The predicate 'is a complex task given the availability of' establishes a relationship between the subject and the object by indicating that the subject involves significant challenges or intricacies that are influenced by the presence or accessibility of the object. It suggests that while the subject may be inherently complex, the degree of complexity is contingent upon the resources, tools, or conditions represented by the object.

Predicate-is_encoded_in.label: is encoded in
Predicate-is_encoded_in.description: The predicate 'is encoded in' establishes a relationship where the subject is represented or stored in a specific format or medium denoted by the object. It implies that the subject's information or data is transformed into a structured form that can be utilized or interpreted through the object, which typically refers to various formats or systems of representation.

Predicate-is_important_in.label: is important in
Predicate-is_important_in.description: The predicate 'is important in' establishes a relationship where the subject is recognized as having significant relevance, value, or influence in the context of the object. It indicates that the subject plays a crucial role or contributes meaningfully to the area or field represented by the object.

Predicate-helps_make.label: helps make
Predicate-helps_make.description: The predicate 'helps make' indicates a supportive or facilitative relationship between the subject and the object, where the subject contributes to the process or outcome represented by the object. It suggests that the subject provides assistance, resources, or insights that enable the creation, formulation, or realization of the object, thereby enhancing the effectiveness or quality of the resulting outcome.

Predicate-is_obtained_in.label: is obtained in
Predicate-is_obtained_in.description: The predicate 'is obtained in' indicates a relationship where the subject is derived or acquired through the process or activity represented by the object. It suggests that the subject cannot exist or be realized without the context or method provided by the object, highlighting a dependency on the specific process for its existence or formulation.

Predicate-automates.label: automates
Predicate-automates.description: The predicate 'automates' indicates a process by which the subject performs actions or tasks that facilitate or execute the object without the need for human intervention. It implies that the subject is capable of streamlining, enhancing efficiency, or enabling the execution of the object, which typically involves a systematic or repetitive activity.

Predicate-integrates.label: integrates
Predicate-integrates.description: The predicate 'integrates' denotes the action of combining or unifying different components, systems, or entities into a cohesive whole. It implies a process where the subject effectively incorporates the object, which can be a set of tools, models, or methodologies, to enhance functionality, improve performance, or achieve a specific goal. This integration often involves ensuring compatibility and facilitating interaction between the subject and the object.

Predicate-takes.label: takes
Predicate-takes.description: The predicate 'takes' indicates that the subject is capable of receiving, utilizing, or processing the object. It establishes a relationship where the subject requires the object as an input or resource to perform its function or achieve a specific outcome.

Predicate-processes.label: processes
Predicate-processes.description: The predicate 'processes' indicates an action or function performed by the subject that involves the transformation, manipulation, or handling of the object. In this context, it signifies that the subject is actively engaging with the object in a manner that alters, organizes, or utilizes it to achieve a specific outcome or goal.

Predicate-applies.label: applies
Predicate-applies.description: The predicate 'applies' indicates a relationship where the subject utilizes or implements the object in a relevant context or process. It suggests that the subject is actively engaging with the object in a manner that is intended to achieve a specific outcome or function, thereby demonstrating the practical use or relevance of the object within the framework established by the subject.

Predicate-output.label: output
Predicate-output.description: The predicate 'output' signifies the action or process by which the subject produces or generates the object, typically representing the results, data, or information derived from the subject's operations or functions.

Predicate-takes_as_input.label: takes as input
Predicate-takes_as_input.description: The predicate 'takes as input' indicates that the subject is designed to receive or utilize the object as a necessary component or resource for its operation or function. This relationship implies that the object is essential for the subject to perform its intended tasks or processes.

Predicate-processes_based_on.label: processes based on
Predicate-processes_based_on.description: The predicate 'processes based on' indicates a relationship where the subject is engaged in a series of actions or operations that are fundamentally influenced or guided by the object. In this context, the subject utilizes the object as a foundational element or framework that informs the nature, methodology, or parameters of the processes being executed. This implies that the processes are not arbitrary but are structured and directed by the characteristics or requirements of the object.

Predicate-generates.label: generates
Predicate-generates.description: The predicate 'generates' indicates a relationship where the subject produces, creates, or brings about the object as a result of its function or operation. It implies a causal or productive link between the subject and the object, suggesting that the subject has the capability or role to yield the object in some form.

Predicate-enables.label: enables
Predicate-enables.description: The predicate 'enables' indicates that the subject provides the means, capability, or opportunity for the object to occur or be realized. It suggests a facilitative relationship where the subject empowers or allows the object to be achieved or performed.

Predicate-aids.label: aids
Predicate-aids.description: The predicate 'aids' indicates a supportive or facilitative relationship between the subject and the object, where the subject provides assistance, resources, or enhancements that contribute to the effectiveness or success of the object. In this context, the subject is seen as a means or tool that helps in achieving or advancing the goals associated with the object.

Predicate-provides.label: provides
Predicate-provides.description: The predicate 'provides' indicates a relationship in which the subject offers, supplies, or makes available a particular resource, service, or information to the object. It signifies an act of provision where the subject is the source or provider, and the object is the recipient or the content being supplied.

Predicate-summarizes.label: summarizes
Predicate-summarizes.description: The predicate 'summarizes' indicates a relationship where the subject provides a concise representation or overview of the information contained in the object. It implies that the subject distills the essential points or themes from the object, which consists of more detailed or extensive content.

Predicate-supports.label: supports
Predicate-supports.description: The predicate 'supports' indicates a relationship in which the subject provides assistance, reinforcement, or facilitation to the object, enhancing its functionality, effectiveness, or overall performance. This connection implies that the subject plays a beneficial role in enabling or promoting the capabilities or operations of the object.

Predicate-summarised_in.label: summarised in
Predicate-summarised_in.description: The predicate 'summarised in' indicates a relationship where the subject, which represents a collection of information or data points, is condensed or synthesized into a more concise form represented by the object. This implies that the object serves as a comprehensive overview or representation of the key elements or insights derived from the subject, facilitating easier understanding or communication of the original content.

Predicate-is_a_major_component_in.label: is a major component in
Predicate-is_a_major_component_in.description: The predicate 'is a major component in' indicates that the subject plays a significant and essential role within the context of the object. It suggests that the subject is one of the key elements that contribute to the functionality, effectiveness, or overall structure of the object, highlighting its importance in the given domain.

Predicate-extracts.label: extracts
Predicate-extracts.description: The predicate 'extracts' indicates an action where the subject performs a process of retrieving or obtaining specific elements, data, or insights from a larger set or source, resulting in the object being identified as the outcome of this action.

Predicate-extracts_information_from.label: extracts information from
Predicate-extracts_information_from.description: The predicate 'extracts information from' indicates a process in which the subject identifies, retrieves, and organizes relevant data or insights from the object, which is typically a source of raw or unstructured content. This relationship highlights the subject's capability to transform the object into a more usable or structured form of information.

Predicate-have_resulted_in.label: have resulted in
Predicate-have_resulted_in.description: The predicate 'have resulted in' indicates a causal relationship where the subject has led to or produced the object as a consequence of certain actions, developments, or changes. It implies that the subject's influence or impact has directly contributed to the existence or emergence of the object.

Predicate-enable.label: enable
Predicate-enable.description: The predicate 'enable' signifies a facilitative relationship where the subject provides the necessary means, tools, or conditions that allow or empower the object to occur or be achieved. In this context, it indicates that the subject plays a crucial role in making the action or process represented by the object possible.

Predicate-exist.label: exist
Predicate-exist.description: The predicate 'exist' establishes a relationship between the subject and the object by indicating that the subject has a presence or is found in reality, while the object specifies the nature or type of that presence. In this context, it conveys that the subject is associated with or encompasses the characteristics described by the object.

Predicate-is_difficult_considering.label: is difficult considering
Predicate-is_difficult_considering.description: The predicate 'is difficult considering' establishes a relationship where the subject is perceived as challenging or complex due to the influence or presence of the object. It implies that the difficulties associated with the subject are significantly affected by the factors or conditions represented by the object.

Predicate-required_prior_to_using.label: required prior to using
Predicate-required_prior_to_using.description: The predicate 'required prior to using' establishes a necessary condition or prerequisite that must be fulfilled before the subject can effectively utilize the object. It indicates that the subject involves a preparatory step or process that is essential for the successful application or operation of the object.

Predicate-enhances.label: enhances
Predicate-enhances.description: The predicate 'enhances' indicates a relationship where the subject contributes positively to the quality, effectiveness, or capability of the object. It suggests an improvement or augmentation of the object by the subject, leading to a more advanced or refined state.

Predicate-can_provide.label: can provide
Predicate-can_provide.description: The predicate 'can provide' indicates the capability or potential of the subject to supply, deliver, or make available the object. It establishes a relationship where the subject is positioned as a source or facilitator that offers the object, which represents a resource, service, or functionality that can be utilized or accessed by others.

Predicate-provide.label: provide
Predicate-provide.description: The predicate 'provide' indicates an action where the subject offers, supplies, or makes available something to the object. It establishes a relationship in which the subject is the source or giver of information, resources, or assistance, while the object represents what is being given or made accessible. This connection implies a transfer of knowledge, resources, or support from the subject to the object.

Predicate-introduces.label: introduces
Predicate-introduces.description: The predicate 'introduces' signifies an action where the subject presents or brings attention to the object, often in a context that aims to inform or familiarize the audience with the object. This can involve detailing the characteristics, significance, or relevance of the object, thereby establishing a connection between the subject and the object in a manner that enhances understanding or awareness.

Predicate-is_to_automate.label: is to automate
Predicate-is_to_automate.description: The predicate 'is to automate' indicates the intention or purpose of the subject in relation to the object, suggesting that the subject aims to implement a process or system that will perform the actions associated with the object automatically, thereby enhancing efficiency and reducing the need for manual intervention.

Predicate-from.label: from
Predicate-from.description: The predicate 'from' indicates a source or origin in the relationship between the subject and the object. It connects the subject, which represents an action or process, to the object, which signifies the material, context, or data that is being utilized or referenced in that action. In this way, 'from' establishes a directional flow of information or resources, highlighting where the subject derives its content or basis.

Predicate-used_in.label: used in
Predicate-used_in.description: The predicate 'used in' indicates a functional relationship where the subject is employed or applied within the context of the object. It signifies that the subject serves a purpose or role in facilitating, contributing to, or enabling the processes, activities, or outcomes described by the object.

Predicate-is_integrated_with.label: is integrated with
Predicate-is_integrated_with.description: The predicate 'is integrated with' denotes a relationship where the subject is connected or combined with the object in a way that allows for interaction, collaboration, or functionality between the two entities. This integration implies that the subject and object work together to enhance capabilities, share data, or streamline processes, resulting in a cohesive system or workflow.

Predicate-enables_extraction_of.label: enables extraction of
Predicate-enables_extraction_of.description: The predicate 'enables extraction of' signifies a functional relationship where the subject provides the capability or means to obtain or retrieve specific types of information or data represented by the object. This indicates that the subject is equipped to facilitate the process of accessing or deriving the specified content or metadata, thereby enhancing the ability to gather relevant insights or knowledge.

Predicate-extracts_from.label: extracts from
Predicate-extracts_from.description: The predicate 'extracts from' indicates a relationship where the subject is capable of obtaining or retrieving specific information, data, or content from the object. This implies a process of sourcing or deriving elements from the object, which can encompass a variety of formats, types, or sources, thereby facilitating the transfer or transformation of information.

Predicate-brought_together_with.label: brought together with
Predicate-brought_together_with.description: The predicate 'brought together with' indicates a relationship where the subject is combined or associated with the object, suggesting a collaborative or integrative connection between the two entities. This can imply that they are used in conjunction, share a common purpose, or enhance each other's functionality in a particular context.

Predicate-suited_for.label: suited for
Predicate-suited_for.description: The predicate 'suited for' indicates a relationship where the subject is appropriate or well-matched for the requirements or characteristics of the object. It implies that the subject possesses qualities, features, or capabilities that align with the needs or expectations associated with the object, thereby facilitating effective performance or compatibility in a given context.

Predicate-is_easy.label: is easy
Predicate-is_easy.description: The predicate 'is easy' establishes a relationship between the subject and the object by indicating that the subject can be performed or understood with minimal difficulty in relation to the object. It suggests that the subject's complexity or effort required is low when considering the characteristics or requirements of the object.

Predicate-fills.label: fills
Predicate-fills.description: The predicate 'fills' denotes an action where the subject provides substance, content, or fulfillment to the object, thereby occupying or completing a space, need, or gap that the object represents. It implies a transformation or enhancement of the object by the subject, suggesting that the object is lacking in some way and the subject serves to remedy that deficiency.

Predicate-are_based_on.label: are based on
Predicate-are_based_on.description: The predicate 'are based on' establishes a foundational relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject derives its principles, methods, or structure from the concepts or frameworks represented by the object. It suggests that the subject's existence or functionality is fundamentally supported or informed by the object.

Predicate-identify.label: identify
Predicate-identify.description: The predicate 'identify' denotes the action of recognizing, determining, or establishing the existence or characteristics of the object by the subject. It implies a process where the subject analyzes or evaluates information to categorize or label the object, often resulting in a clearer understanding or classification of the object in question.

Predicate-of.label: of
Predicate-of.description: The predicate 'of' is used to indicate a relationship of belonging, association, or specification between the subject and the object. It connects the subject to the object by expressing that the subject is characterized by, related to, or includes the object in some way. In general, it serves to clarify the nature of the relationship between the two entities, often implying that the object provides a defining context or category for the subject.

Predicate-can_identify.label: can identify
Predicate-can_identify.description: The predicate 'can identify' denotes the ability or capacity of the subject to recognize, distinguish, or classify the object. It implies a functional relationship where the subject possesses the necessary attributes, skills, or mechanisms to accurately detect or categorize the specified object, which can be a concept, entity, or group.
